posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: Looking for some input from teams who have already purchased and used Phoenix Pro on their motors. Did you find it‚Äôs worth the money? Is the added performance using FOC noticeable?

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: This is the first season it is available and from what I‚Äôve seen so far the FOC is still limited. So you may not get a great answer until after the season

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Weren‚Äôt people shearing output shafts on Falcons or something? The 15% power boost from FOC seems like it would make that issue worse.

Also, teams were promised FOC with their purchase of a Falcon 500. On the basis of principles alone, I wouldn‚Äôt spend extra money on it. Most libraries and code from other teams is based on the free Phoenix 5 API so it will be easier to integrate without Pro.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: I really don‚Äôt think the community is assessing the value of FOC based on performance‚Ä¶

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: Someone should bump the stall torque of a Falcon by 15% in one of the drivetrain design tools and see if it matters.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: This game is game to include high speed full field runs. A 15% bump in efficiency can be significant especially towards the end of the match.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
This thread mentions efficiency, power, torque. We wonder what the PRO +15% capability really is.

My team could use 15% more battery life for the same speed (do we just have to multiply our joystick value by 0.85 to get it?).

15% more power for a climb or shoot might not be as useful this year and does the battery drain 15% faster?

As far as buying the option, part of the team thought $100 once in mad money to answer the question wasn‚Äôt too  bad.  Others thought why bother with the hassle and risk of licensing broken motors.

Maybe the deciding factor in the back of our mind was we still don‚Äôt know if we are getting our Falcon500s or not (we have a swerve set - not going to use them without a complete backup which is on order and it‚Äôs almost time to pull the trigger on which motors to use).

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: I‚Äôd love to see performance testing data from an independent source to tell us what the impact of Pro is.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: I think they said 15% power increase, not stall torque. I‚Äôm not sure FOC would affect stall torque here.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: P=IV , so it seems like 1.15P for the same V would imply 1.15I . Multiplying stall torque by 1.15 should give that effect for a first-order model because torque = Kt * current.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Well I‚Äôll be darned. That‚Äôs a big stall torque increase after all. I wonder why though‚Ä¶ sinusoidal 2048-step commutation should yield the same results as FOC commutation at steady state. It could be that the Falcon is doing 6-step commutation in regular Phoenix, but that‚Äôs just speculation‚Ä¶

I also wonder why stall current has increased. Maybe some type of built-in limiter was increased?

Edit: the manual mentions that out of the box, the Falcon does indeed use trapezoidal commutation. It also uses the terms FOC and sinusoidal interchangeably when the two are definitely not interchangeable. I hope that Pro uses true FOC and not regular sinusoidal commutation. Not that it really matters given that it approaches 1kW of peak output power already.

posts.cooked:

posts.name: what?
posts.cooked: realistically speaking it won‚Äôt make much difference because once your pulling around 200 amps of current the motor would probably stop due to heat before you saw any tangible benefits

posts.cooked: Wow that‚Äôs almost half the wattage of my favorite green themed brushless motor with an integrated motor controller
